SubTopics: Use parentheses, brackets, or braces in numerical expressions, and evaluate expressions with these symbols.
Content: What part of the expression below should be calculated first?

SubTopics: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.
Content: Tara baked 6 1/2 dozen cookies. She sold 3 2/6 dozen of the cookies she made. How many dozens of cookies does Tara have remaining?

SubTopics: Measure volumes by counting unit cubes, using cubic cm, cubic in, cubic ft, and improvised units.
Content: Prism A is shown below. The height of Prism B is 2 times the height of Prism A. The length and width of both prisms are the same.
problems/NY17G5M/media/3a.jpg
What is the volume, in cubic inches, of Prism B?

SubTopics: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Content: Which decimal is equivalent to 41/100?

SubTopics: Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 × 100 + 4 × 10 + 7 × 1 + 3 × (1/10) + 9 × (1/100) + 2 × (1/1000).
Content: What number is equivalent to the expanded form shown below?

SubTopics: Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them.
Content: Which phrase is represented by the expression 5 × (36 + 9) ?

A.Choice: the product of 36 and 5, increased by 9

B.Choice: the product of 36 and 9, multiplied by 5

C.Choice: the sum of 36 and 9, multiplied by 5

D.Choice: the sum of 36 and 5, increased by 9

SubTopics: Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.
Content: The value of the digit in the hundreds place in the number 653,841 is 1/10 the value of the digit in the thousands place in which number?

SubTopics: Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole-number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.
Content: The table below lists the number of layers of centimeter cubes, along with the number of cubes in each layer, in each of four rectangular prisms.
problems/NY17G5M/media/9a.jpg
Which rectangular prism has the greatest volume?

SubTopics: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Content: The decimal grid shown below is shaded and marked with Xs to model an expression.
problems/NY17G5M/media/12a.jpg
Which expression could be modeled by this decimal grid?

SubTopics: Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients.
Content: What is the value of the expression 1/5 ÷ 4?

SubTopics: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.
Content: Mia buys 5 yards of ribbon to make bracelets. She needs 18 inches of ribbon to make 1 bracelet. How many bracelets can Mia make if she uses all the ribbon she buys?

SubTopics: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Content: The decimal grids below are shaded to model an expression.
problems/NY17G5M/media/15a.jpg
What is the value of the expression modeled by the decimal grids?

SubTopics: Interpret a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator (a/b = a ÷ b). Solve word problems involving division of whole numbers leading to answers in the form of fractions or mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 3/5?

SubTopics: A cube with side length 1 unit, called a “unit cube,” is said to have “one cubic unit” of volume, and can be used to measure volume.
Content: Tyler completely filled the box shown below with unit cubes, with no gaps or overlaps.
problems/NY17G5M/media/17a.jpg
He then counted the number of cubes that he used to fill the box. What type of measurement is represented by the number of cubes Tyler counted?

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers.
Content: Each student in a class plays one of three sports: soccer, volleyball, or basketball.

:box:• 3/5 of the number of students play soccer

• 1/4 of the number of students play voleybal
What fraction of the number of students play basketball?

SubTopics: Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.
Content: What is the value of 0.1561 rounded to the nearest tenth?

SubTopics: A solid figure which can be packed without gaps or overlaps using n unit cubes is said to have a volume of n cubic units.
Content: The figure below is made of unit cubes.
problems/NY17G5M/media/23a.jpg
How many unit cubes need to be added to the figure so that it will have a total volume of 12 cubic units?

SubTopics: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.
Content: The operation symbol and the exponent are missing in the equation shown below.
Which operation symbol and exponent should go in the boxes to make the equation true?

SubTopics: Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two-dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category.
Content: A square and a rhombus are shown below.
problems/NY17G5M/media/25a.jpg
Which attribute is true of one of the shapes but not of both?

B.Choice: All sides are the same length.

C.Choice: There are two sets of equal angles.

D.Choice: There are two sets of parallel sides.

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Content: Point K is shown on the number line below.
problems/NY17G5M/media/26a.jpg
Which number sentence best describes the value represented by point K?

SubTopics: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
Content: The table below shows the distance some players hit a softball.
problems/NY17G5M/media/27a.jpg
Pablo hit the softball 2 yards. Which player or players hit the softball the same distance as Pablo?

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Use operations on fractions for this grade to solve problems involving information presented in line plots.
Content: The line plot below shows the lengths of all the pieces of string Emma used for an art proejct. She cut all these pieces from one orginal piece of string.
problems/NY17G5M/media/28a.jpg
Emma had 1 foot of string left over. How long, in feet, was the original piece of string?

SubTopics: Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (n×a)/(n×b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.
Content: For which values of k would the product of k/3 x 12 be greater than 12?

A.Choice: for any value of k less than 1 but greater than 0

B.Choice: for any value of k less than 3 but greater than 1

C.Choice: for any value of k equal to 3

D.Choice: for any value of k greater than 3

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.
Content: Each day last wek, Ms. Wilson walked 3/4 mile. What is the total distance, in miles, that Ms. Wilson walked in 4 days?

SubTopics: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with whole-number side lengths by packing it with unit cubes, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths, equivalently by multiplying the height by the area of the base. Represent threefold whole-number products as volumes, e.g., to represent the associative property of multiplication.
Content: A right rectangular prism is shown below. The volume of the prism is determined by using unit cubes.
problems/NY17G5M/media/33a.jpg
Which statement describes how to determine the volume of the prism in cubic units?

A.Choice: Add the length, width, and height: 4 + 3 + 2.

B.Choice: Add the length and width and then multiply by the height: (4 + 3) ×2.

C.Choice: Determine the area of the base and add the number of layers of cubes: (4 x 3) + 2.

D.Choice: Determine the area of the base and multiply by the number of layers of cubes: (4 × 3) x 2.

SubTopics: A cube with side length 1 unit, called a “unit cube,” is said to have “one cubic unit” of volume, and can be used to measure volume.
Content: What is the volume of the cube shown below
problems/NY17G5M/media/36a.jpg

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
Content: During a hike, 3 friends equaly shared 1/2 pound of trail mix. What amount of trail mix, in pounds, did each friend receive?

SubTopics: Comparing the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor, without performing the indicated multiplication.
Content: Which expression has a value greater than 1/2?

SubTopics: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.
Content: A science teacher has 0.4 liter of seawater. She gives each of her 22 students a container and a 5-milliliter spoon. She then asks her students to put two spoonfuls of seawater into their containers. How many milliliters of seawater will be left after all 22 students have filled their containers?

SubTopics: Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients.
Content: What is the value of the expression below?

SubTopics: A solid figure which can be packed without gaps or overlaps using n unit cubes is said to have a volume of n cubic units.
Content: Which phrase best describes a figure with dimensions of 2 unites by 2 unites by 4 unites and a volume of 16 cubic units?

A.Choice: a solid figure that can be filled with 16 cubes that each measure 1 cubic unit

B.Choice: a solid figure that can be filled with 1 cube that measures 16 units on each edge

C.Choice: a solid figure that can be covered with 16 squares that each measure 1 square unit

D.Choice: a solid figure that can be covered with 1 square that measures 16 units on each edge

SubTopics: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Content: Susan determined that the expression below is equal to 7.59.
Which expression can Susan use to check her answer?
